He could've been the best of all time, but he isn't one of the best of all time .. .. It's a shame .. .. You can't just blame a rough childhood on his downfall .. .. Most great fighters had rough childhoods .. .. My grandparents are Polish, and they survived a much harder childhood than Mike Tyson did .. .. Mike Tyson was great to watch because his ability to destroy his opponents was so exciting .. .. He had everything to make him the greatest .. .. Everything, except the ability to deal with competition .. .. Roberto Duran admits it on camera .. .. I smell fear, if you fear me, then you will lose. If you don't fear me, then you can beat me .. .. That goes for Tyson .. Tyson never won back his defeats, he never lost on points because he gave up .. His body was perfect, but his mind and his heart were not qualified for warrior status .. .. It's a fact .. .. I love Mike Tyson , but we have to face facts .. .. He cannot be one of the greatest because the greatest fought the greatest and won, and if they lost, they came back and won .. .. He didn't do that .. .. I coach boxing, and the question I always get asked is::  would Tyson beat Muhammad Ali? Absolutely not, no way, no chance, never in a million years .. .. Muhammad Ali would've outclassed him .. .. Cassius Clay would've beaten the shit out of him .. .. He could've been the greatest

Mike always wanted that father figure in his life and then when Jacobs died he lost his 2nd father figure. After that Mike just became a animal that was let out of the cage. He didn't have anyone to hold that animal back and Mike was just out of hand especially when Don King came into the picture. At least now Mike is in his 50s and the beast inside has calmed down and he's at peace with himself. I love his podcast Hot Box In. Cus D’Amato was an older man at the time of his death, so talking about Cus living throughout Tyson’s entire career to protect him is unrealistic, unfortunately. However, even with that being said, Cus still set Mike up for success after his passing. He positioned Kevin Rooney to continue the style of training Mike required, and set up people like Jim Jacobs and Bill Clayton to manage his career from the business side of things. Don King got involved following Jacobs’ death, and stripped away the layers of protection Cus had installed before his death. It was all down hill after that. Had Rooney remained his trainer, and Jacobs-Clayton managed his career, my personal opinion is that Mike Tyson did not have a ceiling. He could have become far and away the greatest to ever live.

When I was younger, as a German, all boxing I would hear about was basically the Klitschko brothers.
When I was a teenager, I spoke to my father about boxing. He said: "I don't think there'll ever be another boxer like Mike Tyson. That guy was something else. I would set my alarm to like 2 AM so I could watch Mike Tyson fights live, and I was mostly back in bed very soon." I watch this in the light of the Roy Jones fight. Before this, I basically knew that Mike was a once in a lifetime phenomenon that was pretty much consumed by his demons. After watching this, it's really tragic. With such a rough childhood and youth, anyone would be crazy to some degree. What could have been if Cus had lived longer? After he was gone, it appears that Mike just surrounded himself with the wrong people. Used to have a father figure keeping you in check and setting you on a proper course, now there's a bunch of snakes who want to get money off you and don't give a rat's ass about your well-being. Poor Mike. Happy to see that he appears to have set himself straight now.

This is a really nice video. But you can't have a complete video without briefly mentioning the role of Teddy Atlas alongside Cus D'Amato. Although it was nice to see a couple clips of Teddy training him, Cus and Teddy both mentored Mike at the same time. Obviously Cus was the father figure and Teddy the big brother.  As his trainer, Teddy was there from the beginning and with him every single day. Teddy was also Cus' pupil. So Teddy was able to teach Mike everything Cus taught him. Teddy taught him very well. In those early years, he was a crucial part of Mike's development and eventual success, prior to leaving due to the gun altercation.  Cus, Teddy Atlas, Kevin Rooney, Jim Jacobs.... these guys were the glue.... the family that kept him centered and together. Teddy left, then Cus died, then Jacobs died, then Kevin left. That was the final blow. Once Don King got involved and Kevin was forced out, the legend of Mike Tyson as we knew it, would soon be over.  I believe if Tyson stuck with Rooney and stayed close to his roots in the Catskills, he might have retired one day as an undefeated champion.
I’m embarrassed when I look at the heavyweights now, Joshua, Fury, Wilder are all pussies. Tyson was a beast,

If you notice when mike drops buster douglas there is a man in the background with white gloves on. He counts with his hands as well, because when a fighter goes down the referee is supposed to get the other fighter to a neutral corner. After getting the standing fighter to a neutral corner, the referee is supposed to look at the man with the white gloves and pick up the count wherever that guy has it at. But if you look at this fight the man in white gloves was at 2 but the referee started the count at 1. Whenever the referee is at 3 the man in white gloves is at 5. So according to that officials count Buster Douglas gets counted out, and mike retains the title.

I did some boxing myself and i got to hit both the bag and the chin to understand what a boxing shot can mean, and i must say this: Tyson hit so bad that i cannot understand it, i cannot understand where he got so much power, i know that most of the power of an uppercut or a hook comes from shoulder leverage, but still, it is amazingly much. I see this shots, and i have seen them 10000 times over when i was boxing and i could not understand it. The precision of the left shot comes from the right foot, but the perfection of the whole body movement it's truly amazing, i do not think that there will ever be a man who hits so hard ever again, i think Mike had some body advantages, amazing training from the greatest trainers of all "Constantine D'Amato" but most important his power, i think, it  was generated from the pain he felt, i think the fear/frustration/heart broken, all the feelings somehow put him in a state of self defense  and trough that he generated incredible amount of power in his shots.

I was just a teenager when Mike Tyson came out of prison and I remember watching the Pay Per View with McNeely with my Dad.  My Dad said several times during that fight that McNeely was probably just a fall guy that they brought in to make Tyson look good.  From what I remember of that fight, he never really got in there and mixed it up with Tyson.  He was looking kind of smug when he came out and they introduced him.  But, as soon as the bell rang and it was for real, he looked like a clown.  He kept going down and his trainer ended up throwing in the towel to stop the fight.  I remember my Dad being pissed off because that Pay Per View was $60 or $70 and the Tyson fight was a joke!  When Mike Tyson came back from prison, he looked pissed off like he was a man on a mission to prove something to the world that he was a serious threat not to be taken lightly.  If the money, the drugs and the women hadn't gone to his head, he would have been the greatest boxer of all time.  His early career was great but he could have been the greatest if things hadn't gone the way they did.

But the cocaine...the women...the sharks in the industry...they sapped him of that.  He’s scary asf, but I can tell that he’s got a good heart bc Custanado and Jacobs brought that out in him. I truly believe that Mike never wanted to box again after Cus died. I'm not sure he ever really loved boxing, but he did love Cus, and Cus wanted to create one more champion before he died. For a kid who spent the first 15 years of his life never being loved by anyone that's a powerful motivation. After Cus died I think lacing up those gloves and stepping in the ring just carried too much sadness and memories. That's why he started training less and less, then doing more and more drugs to numb himself. 

Even worse, was surrounding himself with people who pretended to love him and being too high and naive to see through it...until it was too late. A snake like Don King easily saw what Mike needed, and he played him like a fiddle while acting like a father figure and robbing him blind. By that point he could never really quit boxing because he didn't know anything else and he had already lost much of his 300 million dollar fortune on drugs and giving Rolls Royces to people he barely knew so that they would like him. 

So he had to keep showing up, even has his speed and skills faded. He had to act crazier and crazier to keep people buying tickets. In a perfect world Cus would've lived 7 or 8 more years and guided Mike to a belt and a 10 good title defenses. Then Cus could've made him hang up the gloves and live off the $200 million he invested for him. Mike could've got into acting and writing a lot sooner and done all the other things he seemed to enjoy much more than boxing. 

Fighters who rely on their speed and reflexes like that don't have long careers because once they they lose a little of that they become much too hittable and can't counter like they used to. Slow footed sluggers like Foreman can fight forever because they never needed speed anyway. Tyson should've been retiring undefeated about 1993, 1995 at the latest. Instead, he was just getting out of prison and would go on to box for another 8 years. 

It's amazing he did as well as he did against Holyfield and Lewis after the years away from the ring and all the drugs. Not to mention the complete lack of training, picking a different trainer for every fight and never listening to them anyway. Evander and Lennox are two of the best heavyweights in history, both top 10 easily by anyone's measure. They would've been tough fights for Mike at any time of his career. But after prison and cocaine and all that? It was almost criminal to trot a shot Tyson out there to take a beating like that. And with his iron chin, he damn sure took a beating. He could've gave up 100 punches earlier in any of those fights and nobody would've said a word but he stood there in front of them and took his beating like man. Just a sad damn story and I hope he's able to stay clean and find some happiness with the rest of his life. 

One last thing - Holyfield is great, has a ton of heart, and was always respectful to Mike after the fights. They even get along today after everything that happened. But it pisses me off that Lewis still likes to talk shit every time someone puts a microphone in front of him. I guess he's earned it because he did win but everyone knows that you didn't beat Mike Tyson as much as you beat ''the ghost of Mike Tyson'', or ''the shell of Mike Tyson.'' If Lennox fought him in 1990 and beat him like that then I'd have no problem but it's too much like when Holmes beat a 40something version of Ali and then acted like he was the greatest ever. Watching Tyson demolish him later still makes me smile, and I'm sure Ali appreciated it too.
